Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that a coronavirus vaccine would be immediately available to the general public after authorization. The experts state that only a limited number of doses will be available in 2020 and the general public may not receive a shot until well into 2021.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the availability of the vaccine by stating that it would be immediately distributed to the general public. The experts clarify that distribution will be prioritized and may not start until mid-October or later.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by incorrectly stating that the vaccine would be immediately available to the general public, contradicting the experts' statements.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide evidence or data to back up the assertion of immediate distribution to the general public.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the vaccine will be immediately available to the general public, which is contradicted by the experts' statements.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation provided in the claim.
